questions.text: How old are you (at time of prostate biopsy)?
questions.helpText: We do not make decisions about prostate cancer treatment based on age alone, but it might be useful for you to know how men your age respond to different treatments and their overall life expectancy.

questions.text: What was your last PSA (Prostate-Specific Antigen) prior to biopsy?
questions.helpText: PSA, especially when combined with prostate volume, is a helpful predictor of prostate cancer outcomes, among several other factors.

questions.text: What is the volume of your prostate?
questions.helpText: Measured on your MRI, or occasionally on ultrasound, prostate volume is necessary to work out your PSA density.

questions.text: What was the Gleason Score of your biopsy?
questions.helpText:
The Gleason score is how we describe the 'grade' of your prostate cancer. It is usually composed of two numbers (e.g. 3+4). The first number is the most common pattern seen, and the second number is the next most common pattern. 

• Gleason 3 is a low-grade cancer.
• Gleason 4 is a medium-grade cancer.
• Gleason 5 is a high-grade cancer.

Knowing your combined score (e.g. 3+4) helps us to give you tailored information about your treatment options.

questions.text: What stage prostate cancer do you have?
questions.helpText: 'Stage' means whether your prostate cancer is in one or more areas of the prostate... The stage of the cancer helps predict how effective different treatments are likely to be

questions.text: Is your prostate cancer visible on MRI?
questions.helpText: Knowing whether the cancer can be seen on an MRI scan helps us guide you about likely treatment outcomes, because on average, cancer that is visible on MRI behaves differently from cancer that is not visible.

questions.text: What is the maximal cancer core length of your biopsy?
questions.helpText: Knowing the maximum length of cancer, in mm, found in your biopsy tells us how big your cancer is and helps us to give you personalised cancer outcomes.

questions.text: Over the past 4 weeks, how often have you leaked urine?
How many pads or adult diapers per day did you usually use to control leakage during the last 4 weeks?
How big a problem, if any, has dripping or leaking urine been for you during the last 4 weeks?
How would you describe the usual QUALITY of your erections during the last 4 weeks?
options: Not firm enough for any sexual activity
Firm enough for masturbation and foreplay only

questions.text: Overall, how big a problem has your sexual function or lack of sexual function been for you during the last 4 weeks?
Have you used any medication or devices to aid/improve erections?
questions.helpText: Knowing about how your erections are before treatment is very helpful in offering a realistic idea about what you personally can expect after treatment.

questions.text: How big a problem, if any, has urgency to have a bowel movement been for you?
Overall, how big a problem have your bowel habits been for you during the last 4 weeks?
